#Text=Get Rid of Weevils ( Flour Bugs )
#Text=If you 've opened your flour and found it crawling with small pests , you probably have weevils .
#Text=Weevils are actually small , reddish-brown beetles that may be able to fly .
#Text=Since weevils can lay a few eggs a day for months , you might be dealing with flour weevils for a while .
#Text=Completely clean your pantry and store your flour in hard , airtight containers .
#Text=It may take some time before you 've removed all of the weevil eggs , but improving your pantry storage will stop weevils in their tracks .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Cleaning and Improving Your Pantry
#Text=Find the source of the weevils .
#Text=Although pantry pests can fly , they usually like to stay near their food source .
#Text=If you 've noticed small reddish brown beetles , weevils , in your flour , they may also be in other foods in your pantry .
#Text=You should also check for weevils near your pet 's food dishes since this may be their source of food .
#Text=Check for weevils in :
#Text=Cereals and grains ( oats , rice , quinoa , bran ) .
#Text=Crackers .
#Text=Spices and herbs .
#Text=Dried pasta .
#Text=Dried fruit .
#Text=Chocolate , candy , and nuts .
#Text=Dried peas or beans .
#Text=Discard any food that has weevils .
#Text=Although you wo n't be able to see the eggs in pantry items , you will be able to see adult weevils .
#Text=Check your flour and pantry products for them and if you find weevils , throw away the food .
#Text=If you do n't see weevils , you can store and use the flour or food .
#Text=You should n't eat any food that could contain live weevils .
#Text=If you 've accidentally baked with flour containing weevils , you can eat the food because the weevils are dead .
#Text=Vacuum and wash your pantry .
#Text=Remove the food from your pantry shelves and use a vacuum attachment to suck up any loose bits of food or flour .
#Text=Take a wash cloth dipped in soapy water and wash all of the shelves and anywhere that there may be spilled food .
#Text=If you 've found weevils in other rooms of your house , vacuum them up .
#Text=Immediately empty the vacuum canister in your dumpster outside so the weevils do n't stay in your kitchen trashcan .
#Text=You wo n't need to use commercial insecticides for weevils or pantry moths if you clean your pantry and remove their food source .
#Text=Wipe your pantry shelves with white vinegar or eucalyptus oil .
#Text=Once you 've thoroughly cleaned your pantry shelves , wipe them with a liquid that weevils dislike .
#Text=You can wipe a mixture of half water and half white vinegar or use eucalyptus oil .
#Text=Just dilute the eucalyptus oil with a little water and spray it onto the shelves .
#Text=You can also try neem , tee tree , or pine needle oils to prevent the weevils from getting into your pantry .
#Text=Place all of your foods in airtight , hard containers .
#Text=Since weevils can eat through cardboard boxes or bags , you 'll need to store your pantry foods in hard plastic containers or jars that are air-tight .
#Text=If you 've bought bakery mixes ( like cake or muffin mixes ) , check these for weevils and transfer them to containers .
#Text=You can color code or label your containers to make them easy to use .
#Text=You may want to cut out any cooking instructions from cardboard packages for foods and store them in an organizer in your kitchen .
#Text=Preventing Weevil Infestations
#Text=Buy smaller amounts of flour .
#Text=If you do n't use very much flour , consider buying small amounts at a time .
#Text=If you leave flour sitting around for a long period of time , weevils may be encouraged to lay their eggs in it .
#Text=The faster you use your flour , the fresher it is , and the fewer the chances for infestation .
#Text=Freeze the flour .
#Text=As soon as you bring flour home , seal it inside a freezer bag and put it in the freezer for at least 1 week .
#Text=This will kill any eggs or weevils that are already in the flour .
#Text=You can then take the flour out and store it in your pantry in an airtight , hard container or just keep it in the freezer until you need it .
#Text=Place a fresh bay leaf in the flour .
#Text=Get out fresh bay leaves and put one in each container or bag of stored flour .
#Text=Some people believe bay leaves can prevent weevil infestations .
#Text=You 'll need to replace the bay leaves every few months or when you can no longer smell them .
#Text=You can find fresh bay leaves in the produce department near the other fresh herbs .
#Text=Use pheromone traps .
#Text=You can buy small packages of weevil traps that use pheromones to attract the weevils and pantry moths .
#Text=The traps have a sticky space that trap the pantry pests .
#Text=Place a few of these around your pantry and change them once they 're full .
#Text=If you are overwhelmed by a huge infestation of weevils ( for example , thousands are crawling all over your floors and walls ) , you may want to contact a pest control professional .
#Text=Check your pantry for weevils on a regular basis .
#Text=You should check your pantry every month or two for weevils .
#Text=This is especially important because adult weevils can live at least a year .
#Text=Remember to thoroughly clean out hard-to-reach parts of your pantry where weevils might start thriving .
#Text=This is a good chance to wash down the pantry shelves again .
#Text=Keeping a clean pantry will prevent flour weevils from coming back .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Do not throw contaminated food away in your kitchen .
#Text=Take it to the outside dumpster to prevent the weevils from re-infesting your pantry .
#Text=If you 've just purchased the flour that you found weevils in , consider sealing the bag in an airtight container and returning it to the store where you bought it .
#Text=If you have contact paper lining your cupboards , remove it before you clean the cupboards since weevils can hide underneath it .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Hard , airtight containers
#Text=Vacuum
#Text=Cloth
#Text=Dish soap
#Text=Eucalyptus oil or vinegar
#Text=Plastic freezer bags
#Text=Bay leaves
#Text=Quick Summary
